Team Fortress 2 is a 2007 multiplayer first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve Corporation. It is the sequel to the 1996 Team Fortress mod for Quake and its 1999 remake, Team Fortress Classic. The game was released in October 2007 as part of The Orange Box for Windows and the Xbox 360, and ported to the PlayStation 3 in December 2007.[1][2] It was released as a standalone game for Windows in April 2008, and updated to support Mac OS X in June 2010 and Linux in February 2013. It is distributed online through Valve's digital retailer Steam, with Electronic Arts managing retail and console editions.

Players join one of two teamsâ€”RED or BLUâ€”and choose one of nine character classes to play as, with game modes including capture the flag and king of the hill. Development was led by John Cook and Robin Walker, the developers of the original Team Fortress mod. Team Fortress 2 was announced in 1998 under the name Team Fortress 2: Brotherhood of Arms. Initially, the game had more realistic, militaristic visuals and gameplay, but this changed over the protracted nine years of development. After Valve released no information for six years, Team Fortress 2 regularly featured in Wired News' annual vaporware list among other entries. Finally released on the Source game engine in 2007, Team Fortress 2 would preserve much of the core class-based gameplay of its predecessors while featuring an overhauled, cartoon-like visual style influenced by the works of J. C. Leyendecker, Dean Cornwell, and Norman Rockwell, alongside an increased focus on the visual and verbal characterization of its playable classes and what the developers have described as a 1960s spy movie aesthetic.

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore

  In the past, Blizzard was a true industry conscience and benchmark, and even more widely circulated: 'When Blizzard produces, it must be a high-quality product.' Evaluation of. Each game is a heavyweight masterpiece in various fields. When I first saw the game "Watch Pioneer", it was undoubtedly impressive. Its excellent quality made it a global sensation, and it also won the TGA Game of the Year award in 2016. This is the only online game in this award, which shows its high value. But later on, Blizzard gradually changed, becoming arrogant, foolish, and mercenary. It was no longer Blizzard that cared about players playing games with their hearts. Poor operations and outdated updates have driven away countless players. The official inaction, the rigidity and stench of the gaming environment have led to fewer and fewer players playing games. The later version of OW2 was even more unsightly. The previous promises were like farting. After the game was modified, it was not even as fun as OW1, which had not been updated for several years. No matter how much games were played and players were still online, 5v5 not only reduced players' satisfaction but also reduced their competitive appearance. After that, Blizzard's arrogant withdrawal from China made countless people feel cold. After so many years of playing, just one word from you won't let people play? Are you in a hurry to join Steam now that there are fewer people playing games, and you want to make another round of money? Sorry, no one will believe your lies anymore. This game used to be a good one, but to this day, it is purely Blizzard's own fault. Finally, I wish Activision Blizzard CEO Bobby Kotick an early bankruptcy.
